title: Categorical Data â€“ MSDA IFP
text:
2 Worked Example
Consider the dataset provided in datasets/HollywoodMovies.csv, containing 1295 observations on the following 15 variables:








Variable Name
Description




Movie
Title of the movie


LeadStudio
Primary U.S. distributor


RottenTomatoes
Critics' rating (Rotten Tomatoes)


AudienceScore
Audience rating (Rotten Tomatoes)


Genre
Film genre (e.g., Action Adventure, Comedy, Thriller)


TheatersOpenWeek
Number of screens on opening weekend


OpeningWeekend
Opening weekend gross (in millions)


BOAvgOpenWeekend
Average box office income per theatre, opening weekend


Budget
Production budget (in millions)


DomesticGross
U.S. gross income (in millions)


ForeignGross
Foreign gross income (in millions)


WorldGross
Worldwide gross income (in millions)


Profitability
Worldwide gross as a percentage of budget


OpenProfit
Percentage of budget recovered on opening weekend


Year
Year of release







These data were compiled from Box Office Mojo, The Numbers, and Rotten Tomatoes.

We load the tidyverse package as we will use the functions
read_csv() and glimpse() from this package.


Load tidyverse and import the data

library(tidyverse)


read_csv() reads CSV (comma-separated values) files.
The loaded data are stored in an object called movies using the arrow <-.


movies <- read_csv("HollywoodMovies.csv")


movies <- movies |>
  select(1:15)

glimpse(movies)

Rows: 1,295
Columns: 15
$ Movie            <chr> "2016: Obama's America", "21 Jump Street", "A Late Quâ€¦
$ LeadStudio       <chr> "Rocky Mountain Pictures", "Sony Pictures Releasing",â€¦
$ RottenTomatoes   <dbl> 26, 85, 76, 90, 35, 27, 91, 56, 11, 44, 93, 63, 87, 9â€¦
$ AudienceScore    <dbl> 73, 82, 71, 82, 51, 72, 62, 47, 47, 63, 82, 51, 63, 9â€¦
$ Genre            <chr> "Documentary", "Comedy", "Drama", "Drama", "Horror", â€¦
$ TheatersOpenWeek <dbl> 1, 3121, 9, 7, 3108, 3039, 132, 245, 2539, 3192, 3, 1â€¦
$ OpeningWeekend   <dbl> 0.03, 36.30, 0.08, 0.04, 16.31, 24.48, 1.14, 0.70, 11â€¦
$ BOAvgOpenWeekend <dbl> 30000, 11631, 8889, 5714, 5248, 8055, 8636, 2857, 449â€¦
$ Budget           <dbl> 3.0, 42.0, NA, NA, 68.0, 12.0, NA, 7.5, 35.0, 50.0, 1â€¦
$ DomesticGross    <dbl> 33.35, 138.45, 1.56, 1.55, 37.52, 70.01, 1.99, 3.01, â€¦
$ WorldGross       <dbl> 33.35, 202.81, 6.30, 7.60, 137.49, 82.50, 3.59, 8.54,â€¦
$ ForeignGross     <dbl> 0.00, 64.36, 4.74, 6.05, 99.97, 12.49, 1.60, 5.53, 9.â€¦
$ Profitability    <dbl> 1334.00, 482.88, NA, NA, 202.19, 687.50, NA, 113.87, â€¦
$ OpenProfit       <dbl> 1.20, 86.43, NA, NA, 23.99, 204.00, NA, 9.33, 32.57, â€¦
$ Year             <dbl> 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012,â€¦




3.1 Visualising categorical variables



Variable
Why categorical?




Movie
Unique labels (ID variable)


LeadStudio
Qualitative categories


Genre
Qualitative categories


Year
Distinct categories, not continuous numeric data



You will createÂ bar plotsÂ for:

Genre
LeadStudio
Year

Bar plots are the standard way to display categorical frequencies.

Genre frequency plot

plot_genre <- ggplot(movies, aes(x = Genre)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(x = "Movie Genre", y = "Frequency") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust = 1))
plot_genre










LeadStudio frequency plot

library(tidyverse)
library(forcats)

plot_LeadStudio  <- ggplot(movies, aes(x = fct_infreq(LeadStudio))) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(
    x = "Lead Studio (sorted by frequency)",
    y = "Count",
    title = "Frequency of Lead Studios"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    breaks = seq(0, 150, by = 20)   # More detailed count axis
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(
      angle = 45,
      hjust = 1,
      size = 6,                    # Smaller labels so they fit
      lineheight = 0.8
    ),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 9)
  )

plot_LeadStudio








Flip

ggplot(movies, aes(x = fct_infreq(LeadStudio))) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(x = "Lead Studio (sorted by frequency)", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 150, by = 10))










Show only the top N studios (recommended)
Most analyses only need theÂ most frequentÂ studios.

library(tidyverse)

top_studios <- movies |>
  count(LeadStudio) |>
  arrange(desc(n)) |>
  slice_head(n = 10)   # top 10 studios
top_studios

# A tibble: 10 Ã— 2
   LeadStudio                              n
   <chr>                               <int>
 1 Warner Bros.                          136
 2 Universal Pictures                    114
 3 Lionsgate                             106
 4 Twentieth Century Fox                 103
 5 Paramount Pictures                     76
 6 Sony Pictures Releasing                72
 7 Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures    72
 8 Focus Features                         46
 9 Sony Pictures Classics                 44
10 Fox Searchlight Pictures               42



# Plot with readable labels
ggplot(top_studios, aes(x = fct_reorder(LeadStudio, n), y = n)) +
  geom_col(fill = "grey40") +
  labs(
    x = "Lead Studio",
    y = "Count",
    title = "Top 10 Most Common Lead Studios"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(
      angle = 45,
      hjust = 1,
      vjust = 1
    )
  )









slice(1:10)Â limits the graph to the top 10 studios â†’ readable.
fct_reorder()Â orders bars by frequency.
angle = 45Â rotates labels so they donâ€™t overlap.
base_size = 14Â makes everything easier to read.

If you wantÂ horizontal barsÂ (even cleaner for long labels), use:

ggplot(top_studios, aes(x = n, y = fct_reorder(LeadStudio, n))) +
  geom_col(fill = "grey40") +
  labs(
    x = "Count",
    y = "Lead Studio",
    title = "Top 10 Most Common Lead Studios"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14)








This horizontal version is often the best for categorical names.


Thinking question: Should we plot Movie Titles?

ggplot(movies, aes(x = Movie)) + geom_bar()














Would plotting movie titles give any useful insight?



-Movie is an identifier variable: each title appears only once. -A bar plot of titles would have hundreds of bars of height 1, which is very hard to read and does not summarise the data. -In reports, we usually do not visualise ID variables; instead, we focus on variables that group observations into meaningful categories (such as Genre or LeadStudio).




Year frequency plot

ggplot(movies, aes(x = factor(Year))) +
geom_bar() +
labs(
x = "Year of Release",
y = "Frequency",
title = "Number of Movies Released per Year"
) +
theme_minimal() +
theme(
axis.text.x = element_text(
angle = 45,
hjust = 1
)
)











3.2 Frequency tables with percentages
Genre frequency table

library(tidyverse)
library(kableExtra)


Attaching package: 'kableExtra'


The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':

    group_rows

# Genre frequency table
tbl_genre <- movies |>
  count(Genre, name = "n") |>
  mutate(
    Percent = round((n / sum(n)) * 100, digits = 2)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(n))

tbl_genre

# A tibble: 12 Ã— 3
   Genre               n Percent
   <chr>           <int>   <dbl>
 1 Drama             386   29.8 
 2 Comedy            191   14.8 
 3 Action            170   13.1 
 4 Adventure         164   12.7 
 5 Thriller          155   12.0 
 6 Horror             85    6.56
 7 Romantic Comedy    49    3.78
 8 Documentary        41    3.17
 9 Black Comedy       22    1.7 
10 Musical            18    1.39
11 Western            10    0.77
12 Concert             4    0.31


LeadStudio frequency table

# LeadStudio frequency table
tbl_studio <- movies |>
  count(LeadStudio, name = "n") |>
  mutate(
    Percent = round((n / sum(n)) * 100, digits = 2)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(n))

tbl_studio

# A tibble: 99 Ã— 3

   <chr>                               <int>   <dbl>

10 Fox Searchlight Pictures               42    3.24
# â„¹ 89 more rows



tbl_studio_top10 <- tbl_studio |>
  slice(1:10)


Formatting tables nicely

kbl(
  list(
    tbl_genre,
    tbl_studio_top10
  ),
  booktabs = TRUE,

(using the corresponding chunk labels, e.g.Â {r genre-table}Â andÂ {r studio-table}Â for the chunks that create eachÂ kbl).



What is the most common category?

Most common genreÂ = category with the highest frequency
Most common lead studioÂ = category with the highest frequency

You can identify this from theÂ sortedÂ tables or by usingÂ slice_max():

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
This guide will help you get set up with R and RStudio for the IFP statistics and data skills modules. Please work through it before or during the first lab.


You have two main ways of using R and RStudio.


For the MSDA tutorial sessions, you will use the university computers, which already haveÂ RÂ andÂ RStudioÂ installed. You doÂ notÂ need to download or install anything yourself.



Sit at any available computer in the lab.
Log in using yourÂ university email addressÂ andÂ password.

This is the same login you use for Learn and Outlook, university email, and other campus systems.





Once you are logged in:

Click on theÂ Start MenuÂ (bottom left).
TypeÂ RStudioÂ in the search bar.
Click theÂ RStudioÂ application when it appears.

RStudio will open and start an R session automatically.
You do not need to install or configure anything.




If you prefer to work on your own laptop, install R and then RStudio Desktop.

InstallÂ RÂ from the official website:
https://cran.r-project.org/
Choose your operating system (Windows, macOS, or Linux) and follow the download and install instructions.
InstallÂ RStudio DesktopÂ from:
https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Once installed, openÂ RStudio. It should automatically find your R installation.

You only need to install R and RStudio once. After that you just open RStudio.




It is good practice to keep all the files for a course in one project folder.

In yourÂ DocumentsÂ (or another sensible location), create a new folder called e.g.Â IFP_Stats.
Open RStudio.
In the top-right of RStudio, clickÂ Project (None) > New Projectâ€¦.
ChooseÂ Existing Directory.
ClickÂ Browse, select your newÂ IFP_StatsÂ folder, then clickÂ ChooseÂ (orÂ Open), and finallyÂ Create Project.

You should now see the project name at the top-right of RStudio. Any files you create will live inside this folder.

https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Once installed, openÂ RStudio. It should automatically find your R installation.

You only need to install R and RStudio once. After that you just open RStudio.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
It is good practice to keep all the files for a course in one project folder.

In yourÂ DocumentsÂ (or another sensible location), create a new folder called e.g.Â IFP_Stats.
Open RStudio.
In the top-right of RStudio, clickÂ Project (None) > New Projectâ€¦.
ChooseÂ Existing Directory.
ClickÂ Browse, select your newÂ IFP_StatsÂ folder, then clickÂ ChooseÂ (orÂ Open), and finallyÂ Create Project.

You should now see the project name at the top-right of RStudio. Any files you create will live inside this folder.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
Everything you type in theÂ ConsoleÂ is sent directly toÂ R. The rest of the interface helps you organise, edit, and visualise your work.

# Try your first R command
2 + 2

[1] 4


You should see:
[1] 4

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
3.1 Storing values in Râ€™s memory
In R, you create and store values by assigning them to a name. The assignment operator is:
<-
This symbol is pronouncedÂ â€œarrowâ€, and it tells R to store a value in a named object.
The general structure is:
[name] <- [value]
For Example:

x <- 5

This creates an object calledÂ xÂ and stores the valueÂ 5Â inside it.

Rules for naming objects
There are a few important rules to follow when choosing names in R.

1. No spaces
Names cannot contain spaces.

lucky_number <- 5    âœ”
lucky number <- 5    âœ˜

(The spacesÂ aroundÂ <-Â do not matter; only spacesÂ insideÂ the name are not allowed.)


2. Names must start with a letter
A name must begin with a letter, not a number.

lucky_number <- 5     âœ”
1lucky_number <- 5    âœ˜



3. R is case sensitive
Capital letters matter.

lucky_number
Lucky_Number

These refer toÂ differentÂ objects.


4. Some words cannot be used as names
R has a set ofÂ reserved wordsÂ that already have a special meaning. These include:
if,Â else,Â for,Â in,Â TRUE,Â FALSE,Â NULL,Â NA,Â NaN,Â function
You do not need to memorise these. If you accidentally try to use one, R will warn you.



Objects appear in the Environment pane
After running a line such as:

x <- 5

Here we have created an object calledÂ xÂ with the value 5. You can now useÂ xÂ in later calculations. You should also seeÂ xappear in theÂ EnvironmentÂ pane.

Try using the storedÂ x:

x

[1] 5

x * 3

[1] 15

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
4.1 Creating an R script

Go toÂ File > New File > R Script.
In the new script window (top left), type:


x <- 210
y <- 15
x / y

[1] 14



Put your cursor on the first line and press:


Ctrl + EnterÂ (Windows)
Cmd + EnterÂ (macOS)

R sends that line to the Console and runs it, then moves your cursor to the next line. Press it again to run the next lines.

Now changeÂ xÂ to another number and re-run the lines.

To save your script:

ClickÂ File > Save.
Give it a sensible name, e.g.Â week1_examples.R, and save it in yourÂ IFP_StatsÂ project folder.

You should now see the file listed under theÂ FilesÂ tab (bottom right).

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
4.2 A very simple plot
Add this line at the bottom of your script:

plot(1, 5)








Run it. A small plot should appear in theÂ PlotsÂ tab.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
section: 5.1 Creating your first R Markdown file
text:
5.1 Creating your first R Markdown file

Go toÂ File > New File > R Markdownâ€¦.
In the pop-up:

Title: e.g.Â IFP Intro Lab
Author: your name
Leave â€œHTMLâ€ as the default output for now.

ClickÂ OK. RStudio creates a template document.

Delete everythingÂ belowÂ the first code chunk so you start with a mostly empty file.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
section: 5.2 Adding and running a code chunk
text:
5.2 Adding and running a code chunk
Insert a new R code chunk by either:

ClickingÂ Insert > RÂ at the top of the editor, or
PressingÂ Ctrl + Alt + IÂ (Windows) orÂ Option + Cmd + IÂ (macOS).

Inside the grey chunk, type:

print("Hello from the IFP!")

[1] "Hello from the IFP!"


You can run the chunk in three ways:

Put the cursor on the first line and pressÂ Ctrl/Cmd + EnterÂ repeatedly.
Click the small green play button at the top right of the chunk.
With the cursor inside the chunk, pressÂ Cmd + Shift + EnterÂ (macOS) orÂ Ctrl + Shift + EnterÂ (Windows).

The output appears just under the chunk.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
section: 5.3 Loading packages in an R Markdown file
text:
5.3 Loading packages in an R Markdown file
At the top of your document, in the first code chunk, add:

# Packages used in this document
library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.4     âœ” readr     2.1.5
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.1
âœ” ggplot2   3.5.2     âœ” tibble    3.3.0
âœ” lubridate 1.9.4     âœ” tidyr     1.3.1
âœ” purrr     1.1.0     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


This assumes you have installed theÂ tidyverseÂ package (see below). Any messages that appear under the chunk are fine; they are just information.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
5.4 Writing headings and text
Outside code chunks, you write text as usual. R Markdown uses theÂ # symbolÂ to create headings in the final document. For example:
# R code examples

In this section we will try some basic R commands.
Heading levels work as follows:

#Â gives a main heading,
##Â gives a subheading,
###Â gives a smaller subheading, and so on.


Be aware that:

Inside code chunks,Â #Â creates an RÂ commentÂ that R will ignore.
Outside code chunks,Â #Â creates aÂ headingÂ in the report.


5.5 â€œSourceâ€ and â€œVisualâ€ modes
RStudio provides two ways of editing an R Markdown document:

Source mode
This shows the raw Markdown file, including:

code chunks,
formatting symbols (e.g.Â #,Â **bold**,Â *italics*),
and output-format instructions.

Use this mode when you want full control over your document.



Visual mode
This behaves more like a word processor:

You see headings, formatting, and lists as they will appear in the final document,
Code chunks are shown as blocks that you can edit without typing backticks.

Visual mode is easier for beginners, but Source mode is useful once you want more precision in formatting.
You can switch between them at any time using theÂ Source/VisualÂ toggle at the top left of the editor.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
6.1 Installing tidyverse
You only need to install a packageÂ once per computer.
In the Console (not in an R Markdown chunk), type:

install.packages("<package name>")


install.packages("tidyverse")

and pressÂ Enter. This will download and install the package. It may take a few minutes.
On some university servers tidyverse may already be installed. If so,Â install.packages()Â is not necessary there.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
6.2 Loading a package
Each time you start RStudio, you need toÂ loadÂ any packages you want to use:

library(<package name>)


library(tidyverse)

You usually put theseÂ library()Â calls near the top of your script or R Markdown file so that anyone reading your code can see which packages they need.
The next time you begin an R session, youâ€™ll have to reload the package with library if you want to use it, but you wonâ€™t have to reinstall it. You only have to install each package once.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
section: 7.1 Creating and saving a small data set
text:
7.1 Creating and saving a small data set

Open Excel, LibreOffice Calc, Google Sheets or similar.
Create a tiny data set, for example:

Column 1:Â student
Column 2:Â score

Fill in a few rows with names and marks.
Save the file asÂ CSV (Comma-Separated Values)Â and call it something likeÂ ifp_scores.csv.
Make sure you save it inside yourÂ IFP_StatsÂ project folder.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
7.2 Reading the CSV into R
In a new code chunk in your R Markdown file, or in a script, type:

library(tidyverse)

scores <- read_csv("ifp_scores.csv")

Rows: 5 Columns: 2
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (1): student
dbl (1): score

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

scores

# A tibble: 5 Ã— 2
  student score
  <chr>   <dbl>
1 Ana        82
2 Sam        74
3 Jae        91
4 Luis       67
5 Mira       88


Helpful tip: if your cursor is between the quotation marksÂ " "Â insideÂ read_csv("")Â and you pressÂ Tab, RStudio will show a list of files in your project so you can choose the correct name.
The objectÂ scoresÂ should now appear in theÂ EnvironmentÂ pane. To see how many rows and columns there are, use:

dim(scores)

[1] 5 2


To see the structure of the data:

glimpse(scores)

Rows: 5
Columns: 2
$ student <chr> "Ana", "Sam", "Jae", "Luis", "Mira"
$ score   <dbl> 82, 74, 91, 67, 88

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
8.1 Start with a clean workspace

Go toÂ Tools > Global Optionsâ€¦.
UnderÂ General, untickÂ â€œRestore .RData into workspace at startupâ€.
SetÂ â€œSave workspace to .RData on exitâ€Â toÂ â€œNeverâ€.
ClickÂ ApplyÂ andÂ OK.

This means RStudio will start with an empty workspace each time, so you must re-run your scripts to recreate objects. This is good practice and avoids confusing â€œleft-overâ€ objects.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio â€“ IFP
text:
8.2 Wrap long lines of code

Go toÂ Tools > Global Optionsâ€¦Â again.
ClickÂ CodeÂ in the left-hand menu.
TickÂ â€œSoft-wrap R source filesâ€.
ClickÂ ApplyÂ andÂ OK.

Now long lines of code will wrap inside the editor, so you do not have to scroll sideways.

title: Research Design & Data â€“ MSDA IFP
text:
In the tutorial you were asked to work with the CollegeScores_teaching.csv dataset.
Below is one way to read the data and inspect its structure.



library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.4     âœ” readr     2.1.5
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.1
âœ” ggplot2   3.5.2     âœ” tibble    3.3.0
âœ” lubridate 1.9.4     âœ” tidyr     1.3.1
âœ” purrr     1.1.0     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

     Asian      Other 
        24         24 


summary()Â flags variables withÂ NAs, andÂ colSums(is.na(college))Â gives the exact number of missing values in each column. In this teaching file there are relatively few missing values across variables.



A dataset containing information onÂ 400 higher-education institutions in the United StatesÂ was analysed. The dataset includes variables describing each institutionâ€™s geographical location (state, region, and local setting), sector type (public, private, or for-profit), and whether it represents a main or branch campus. Several numeric variables provide information on undergraduate enrolment, proportions of part-time students, and costs such as in-state and out-of-state tuition. The dataset also reports the demographic composition of each institutionâ€™s student body, including the percentage of students identifying as White, Black, Hispanic, Asian, or Other.
Initial inspection shows substantial variation in enrolment and tuition levels, and a small amount of missing data (for example, 1 missing value inÂ Locale, 24 missing values inÂ Enrollment,Â PartTime,Â White,Â Black,Â Hispanic,Â Asian, andÂ Other, and 36 missing inÂ TuitionInÂ andÂ TuitionOut). Overall, the dataset offers a clear structure suitable for exploring relationships between institutional characteristics, costs, and student demographics.

summary()Â flags variables withÂ NAs, andÂ colSums(is.na(college))Â gives the exact number of missing values in each column. In this teaching file there are relatively few missing values across variables.



A dataset containing information onÂ 400 higher-education institutions in the United StatesÂ was analysed. The dataset includes variables describing each institutionâ€™s geographical location (state, region, and local setting), sector type (public, private, or for-profit), and whether it represents a main or branch campus. Several numeric variables provide information on undergraduate enrolment, proportions of part-time students, and costs such as in-state and out-of-state tuition. The dataset also reports the demographic composition of each institutionâ€™s student body, including the percentage of students identifying as White, Black, Hispanic, Asian, or Other.
Initial inspection shows substantial variation in enrolment and tuition levels, and a small amount of missing data (for example, 1 missing value inÂ Locale, 24 missing values inÂ Enrollment,Â PartTime,Â White,Â Black,Â Hispanic,Â Asian, andÂ Other, and 36 missing inÂ TuitionInÂ andÂ TuitionOut). Overall, the dataset offers a clear structure suitable for exploring relationships between institutional characteristics, costs, and student demographics.
